column1: Dear David Hardy, It is fascinating to watch the organized character assassination of Michael Moore that has been
column3: on in the United States since the release of his last documentary. [SEP] In a time of simple-minded patriotism, loud, clear and dissenting voices like Mr. Moore's are perceived as disturbing and have to be silenced, partially through well funded public relations campaigns, partially through conservative "grass-roots" propaganda. [SEP] Not surprisingly, much of the criticism of Moore's film is misguided or outright wrong, often vastly more inaccurate than Moore's work itself. [SEP] Moore portrays the NRA as an unethical, dishonest organization; he sees the paranoia and fear in the United States as a primary cause of violence, and he does not see gun ownership itself as a problem. [SEP] His documentary is full of subtle humor, jaw-dropping dialogue and dark contrasts. [SEP] All in all, it is

[SEP] Walking through an alley with rubbish piles that occasionally skittered from one wall to the other, he did not inspire confidence. [SEP] “Just at this corner,” he said, interrupting my immanent panic attack, “we’re
column3: to stop and turn three times widdersh – er, counterclockwise, then face east. East is that way.” [SEP] He pointed at the wall to our right. [SEP] “Don’t let the sun fool you. Then I’m

column1: “Oh, thanks, Nepthys, for your confidence-inspiring tales of experience. So they’re probably worse than we think, okay, that’s great. Now can you tell me what your master plan of attack will be before we go spinning counterclockwise into an Anne Rice novel?” “My plan is that you shut up while we’re trying to conduct business with someone who might be able to tell us what we’re actually
column3: up against. Okay? Don’t forget, she’s your girlfriend. Now calm down while I talk to this gentleman. I can hear your heartbeat from over here.” [SEP] I shut up and tried to breathe. [SEP] Nepthys turned back to the little man on the bed, who had not moved. [SEP] “Please, accept our apologies. As you can see, our situation is of personal importance to the young man. Now: may we ask you a few questions about an individual we believe to be a vampire? It would be a great help to us.”

column1: We hit a bar on the next street over. [SEP] “Vodka, straight up,” Nepthys told the bartender as we sat down at the counter, “and a Bloody Mary for my friend. Make it extra bloody.” [SEP] When our drinks came, he poured a dollop of something from an inner pocket into my Bloody Mary. [SEP] “That should help,” he said. [SEP] “You could run on empty with a little of that stuff. It won’t refill your blood supply, but while that’s in your system, you won’t even need blood.” [SEP] He grinned at me. [SEP] “Drink up, kid.” [SEP] I took about half of the Bloody Mary in one gulp and then ate the celery. [SEP] Nepthys slapped me on the back. [SEP] “Okay,” I said, “now that we’re sitting down, can you explain a little more of what’s
column3: on here? I mean, what is this place, really?” [SEP] He thought about that. [SEP] “I think that our world is a reflection of yours, or yours is a more boring reflection of ours. This place is just a little of both. In America, things are still weird after the European conquest. The natives are still here, but so is everyone else. The Europeans mostly manifest as something like the underground society of your cities. We aren’t quite what you’d expect from reading the Grimms.”

column1: “My parents came over from Russia, just like your family. My real name is a little more ethnically appropriate, but we don’t toss those around in this place. They were spirits of a certain branch of the Volga and the village based around a mill on that tributary. When the Russian government dammed the river, my parents decided that instead of dying with the river, they would stick with the people of the village they’d protected. I was born here, and I was lucky enough not to get attached to any particular river. Sure, I miss having a place to settle down, but it’s better than waiting to get dammed.” [SEP] He took another shot of vodka. [SEP] “Shouldn’t you be
column3: light on the vodka? I mean, we might have a lot of work ahead of us.” “Are you kidding? I can drink like a fish, kid. We should get

column1: We left. [SEP] Nepthys shook his hands at me like he wanted to wrap them around my neck. [SEP] “You idiot,” he hissed, “do you know how much you’ve set us back? I should say, set yourself back, since it’s your girlfriend we’re looking for.” [SEP] I thought about Rachel; in the excitement, I had forgotten why we were chasing down vampire experts. [SEP] “You’re just lucky that Dvorov isn’t my only contact. Come on, we’re heading out.” [SEP] He held the door for me and Amy when we reached the bottom of the stairs. [SEP] Walking outside, I was shocked to see that it was already dark. [SEP] “Night comes quickly here,” said Nepthys quietly as he came out behind me. [SEP] “Didn’t I warn you?” “Okay,” he said as we hit the street, “we’re
column3: to see another friend of mine. First, though, we are getting you a hat. You look ridiculous with a shaved head.” [SEP] At a nearby stand, he grabbed the first hat that would cover my head and might pass back in real Boston. [SEP] It was a black baseball cap that read “Dead Can Dance” in gold across the front. [SEP] Amy liked it, I think. [SEP] She still hadn’t spoken since I named her, so I wasn’t sure. [SEP] He took us to a squat, long building whose roof bulged up like the ribs of a gutted animal. [SEP] The black door opened as we came up to it, and a pale man opened the door. [SEP] He was naked, but there was nothing to hide: his body was hairless and completely smooth. [SEP] I only say “he” because he didn’t have a hint of femininity. [SEP] His eyes were white. [SEP] From behind him, I

column1: “She may be at that,” said Isis, gazing at her. [SEP] “That sweet, small nose, and her soft lips – she’d kiss well, I should think, if gently. She has good blood under her cheeks. Good, round breasts, too, even though they’re small, they suit her.” [SEP] Amy didn’t blush, and I hoped that she didn’t understand what Isis was saying. [SEP] “She would have been worth it,” Nepthys interrupted, “if this fool hadn’t accidentally woken her up before we could give her to our contact. He was
column3: to give us valuable information for her.” “Now I understand why you’re here,” said Isis. [SEP] “So what do you need to know?”

column1: Nepthys caught up with us after a minute and walked silently to the end of the hall. [SEP] When we got there, another pale servant was waiting for us with a box of dark stained wood. [SEP] He offered it to Nepthys, who opened the box: on velvet lining, a wooden hammer and two stakes. [SEP] “Mountain ash,” said Nepthys. [SEP] “That was very kind of her.” [SEP] Closing the box, he paused beside the open door and looked back at me. [SEP] “I really hope we find your Rachel,” he said. [SEP] It looked like he was
column3: to continue, but then he walked out the door. [SEP] “I know a quick way to Dvorov’s,” said Nepthys. [SEP] “I bet he’s kicking himself now for not having a way to contact me.” [SEP] In a few minutes, we were back to the first door we’d knocked on in this town and Dvorov himself was greeting us. [SEP] The pulse from inside made the building sound like a giant heart.

column1: This is Heaven This 85 year old couple, having been married almost 60 years, had died in a car crash. [SEP] They had been in good health the last ten years, mainly due to her interest in health food and exercise. [SEP] When they reached the pearly gates, St. Peter took them to their mansion which was decked out with a beautiful kitchen and master bath suite and Jacuzzi. [SEP] As they "oohed and aahed" the old man asked Peter how much all this was
column3: to cost. [SEP] "It's free," Peter replied, "this is Heaven." [SEP] Next they went out back to survey the championship golf course that the home backed up to. [SEP] They would have golfing privileges everyday and each week the course changed to a new one representing the great golf courses on earth. [SEP] The old man asked, "What are the green fees?" [SEP] Peter's reply, "This is heaven, you play for free."

column1: It was Saturday morning as Jake, an avid hunter, woke up ready to go bag the first deer of the season. [SEP] He walked down to the kitchen to get a cup of coffee, and to his surprise he found his wife, Alice, sitting there, fully dressed in camouflage. [SEP] Jake asked her, "What are you up to?" [SEP] Alice smiled. [SEP] "I'm
column3: hunting with you!" [SEP] Jake, though he had many reservations about this, reluctantly decided to take her along. [SEP] Later they arrived at the hunting site. [SEP] Jake set his wife safely up in the tree stand and told her, "If you see a deer, take careful aim and I'll come running back as soon as I hear the shot."

column1: Price records are being set at auctions this week. [SEP] At Christie's, a folio of 21 prints from Alfred Stieglitz's "Equivalents" series sold for $396,000, a single-lot record. [SEP] Other works also have been exceeding price estimates. [SEP] In part, prices reflect development of a market structure based on such variables as the number of prints. [SEP] This information used to be poorly documented and largely anecdotal, says Beth Gates-Warren of Sotheby's. [SEP] "There is finally some sort of sense in the market," she says. [SEP] Corporations and museums are among the serious buyers, giving greater market stability, says Robert Persky of the Photograph Collector. [SEP] "When I see prints

column1: Xerox Corp. has told employees in its Crum & Forster personal insurance operations that it is laying off about 300 people, or 25% of the staff. [SEP] A spokeswoman for Crum & Forster said employees were told early this week that numerous staff functions for the personal insurance lines were
column3: to be centralized as a cost-cutting move. [SEP] She said the move would result in a after-tax charge of less than $4 million to be spread over the next three quarters. [SEP] By comparison, for the first nine months, Xerox earned $492 million, or $4.55 a share, on revenue of $12.97 billion.

column1: A new continuity What general lessons can be claimed from our two examples? [SEP] Many would argue that traditional employment systems,
column3: back to the factories of the eighteenth century, do not favour boundaryless careers. [SEP] We agree, but we also live in a time when those systems are failing, and where their underlying assumptions of stasis are incompatible with the emergent reality of persistent change. [SEP] Moreover, those systems were designed according to a conception of ‘labour capital’ rather than to one of ‘intellectual capital’. [SEP] Yet, it is the conception of intellectual capital that is increasingly emphasised today. [SEP] Readers of this chapter will most likely see themselves as having a capacity for continuous learning. [SEP] Is it really too great a step to extend the same belief in the capacity for learning to the workforce at large? [SEP] If the workforce at large can learn, what are the social arrange
